description: New York City was a different place in the '70s. "Was it fear or insularity or television or drugs that shut people in?"
title: NYC streets in the 1970s
title_page: NYC streets in the 1970s - Business Insider
text:
Chevrolet Nova, in the Twenties near Avenue of the Americas, 1976 Langdon Clay Riddled with crime, and on the brink of bankruptcy, New York City was a very different place 40 years ago. Unlike most New Yorkers, photographer Langdon Clay spent much of the 1970s walking around Manhattan alone in the middle of the night.
It certainly wasn't the safest way to spend his time, but "being young and foolish can have its advantages," Clay told Business Insider.
While roaming the streets, Clay documented the city's cars, peacefully parked and left for the night, reflecting the neon signs and street lights. Though the photographic focus is on the cars, it's hard to ignore the fact that there are very rarely any other people in the shot. Clay's book, "Cars â€” New York City 1974-1976," is a collection of photos of a New York City that will probably never be that eerily quiet again.
